reviewText:
Oh man, I remember watching my dad play this when I was like 5. Brings back so many memories, and now I get to play it again!

The game is very different than moder TW games. You really have to get used to the comands and camera control. E.g. you don't move units by right clicking but by left clicking (in the battle), and that feels really wierd. The campaign is also completely different, but nothing you can't figure out with a couple of hours of gameplay.

The graphics: what can I say, don't expect much. For a game released in 2000 it is revolutionary. And they made a good job optimizing it. It maybe is pixelated, but it runs and looks smooth, and I personaly love the retro look, it gives a totaly different feeling to the game. It runs in fullscreen on 1920x1080, but only in the campaign and the battles. The main menu doesn't cover the whole screen, which is kind of dissapointing and strange, but not a super big deal.

The music, the sounds, the atmosphere, the graphics. This game, together with Medieval, takes you back in time, when it all started. And to have that oportunity is simply amazing.

If you never played this game but you have played modern TW games, I cannot recommend it enough, get it now !!
voteText: 124 of 132 people (94%) found this review helpful 13 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I almost bought this game from Gamersgate, but I had heard it was impossible to play on newer systems. I borrowed a copy from a friend and, sure enough, it would not start. After developer credits it would crash to desktop every single time. I tried all sorts of fixes, but nothing made the game work. I had no choice but to accept the upsetting fact that it was just completely incompatible with modern software. I was very sad about this because, being a fan of other Total War games, I really wanted to play this one and experience first-hand the evolution of the series.

Can you believe my luck? A week later Creative Assembly/Sega release this game on Steam, updated to run on my OS: Windows 8.1 64-bit, and it works perfectly! Not only that, but they also release Medieval: Total War; which also works! That's not all. The main menu screen is fixed to default resolution, but the in-game resolution can be maxed out to 1920 x 1080, and it looks stunning. Game is still simple-looking, but highly detailed and addicting.

This was a very nice surprise that caught me totally off guard. They've made me one of the happiest gamers today!

reviewText:
Shogun: Total War is a game set in medieval Japan, where the aim is to unite the country under your banner. It has the dated charm of the 00's and lacks the impressive graphics of later Total War games, but it is my contention that this game is a great one in its own right.

One might think that the only reason to get the game is for nostagia's sake. And there is no denying that a significant percentage of the purchases will probably come from old players. One advantage of this copy compared to the old one that you might still own is that it is now compatible mith modern operating systems. I am personnally using windows 7 and have had no problems playing a few turns in the campaign and winning a custom battle. Moreover, the price tag is quite reasonable.

The game is 15 years old and the graphics are no longer up to today's standards. They still have a certain charm to them and it does not prevent having fun at all. In addition, the game offers several campaigns - including one about a hypothetical mongol invasion of Japan.

However, the game is much more than just a means to satiate your nostalgia. The game is different from all Total War games that would follow (barring its successor Medieval), mainly regarding the campaign map. It uses a Risk-like campaign map, which means that movement is much more restrained. This allows for totally different campaign dynamics and really gives a fresh feel to the campaign, at least for Total War veterans who are not used to this campaign-style. One of the main advantages of this system is that it is much simpler and the AI can therefore cope with it significantly better than with the totally open campaign of later iterations. This makes the campaign both fun and challenging, as defeat becomes a very real possibility.

Regarding battles, the principles applied in later iterations were already present in Shogun and the most interesting feature is that there are lots of historical battles, grouped in different historical campaigns (Nobunaga, Ieyasu, Hideyosi and a mongol one). Playing those historical campaigns gives a nice sense of progression and is quite rare in later iterations.

After explaining the pros and cons of the game, I hope that I could convey the particular feel of this game, and I can only commend this game to those who want a different Total War experience!

reviewText:
This was a ground breaking game when it first came out.  And in many ways it holds its own against the newer revisions.  But like most games, the AI is both good, but also full of holes.  AI is just plain hard to write and the devs did a good job on it.  But you see the holes after you have played a lot and thus start to pay attention to certain details.  Eventually you figure out the game loopholes and rediculous exploits and the game looses its luster.  You can currently get a Steam Key for the Gold Edition from Humble for a buck which is quite a deal.  The Gold edition has a few bugs in it but nothing that inhibits gameplay.

To show what I mean about how the AI is limited, consider that it is possible to win a game while never attacking.  You achieve this by:

1. teching up to Geisha and assassinating mercilessly
2. improving your lands for greater KOKU production so you can afford the upgrade path
3. adding units prudently when affordable to not look too weak
4. bribing Ronin armies for cheap units
5. allying with other clans to delay them from attacking you for as long as possible
6. inciting revolts in other clans' provinces around yours to further keep their armies tied up

Note how with this strategy you never have to initiate battle.  You can eliminate all rival clans by 1560 this way.  Give it a try.  It makes for a different kind of game.

reviewText: This is one of those classic games that improved the PC gaming industry! It was a truly groundbreaking game at the time and even today (with the new found love for pixel art) it has a decent gameplay and still offers some decent strategic challenge, well balanced and is just simply very enjoyable. I remember the first time I experienced the Total War battle system, I immediately fell in love with it and played every Total War game since. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=678430360 http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=678416916

reviewText: Sweet Japanese goodness. First Medieval Total War and now this gem too? This right here, coupled with Medieval Total War were my freaking childhood and worth hundreds of hours of game time. I'm so happy to fiercely charge with my 2d sprites against the enemies of my Clan! Plus, how many games can your diplomat get his head chopped off and sent back to you as a declaration of war? That's right... only this one. Into the Sengoku Jidai, once more lads!\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H2jM2ff4yCI

reviewText:
3% chose to embrace Christ for the gunpowder (eh)
25% kill all those ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing buddarebels that will screw your domains and plans of conquest
10% proudly make an army of Arquebus Ashigaru
1% find out that the new Arquebus Ashigaru sucks
1% learn after some nerd searching that the gunpowder of those Ashigaru didn't work when raining (need to upgrade them to Musketeers Ashigaru)
10% curse (but love) the realism of this game
20% build a Kensai and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• the realism
30% OP cavalry

The first of the TW series, nothing more to say. Also, following the teachings of Sun Tzu, I got my revenge after all those years, remembering when my old PC couldn't manage so much CPU requirements when this game was released. Now with a GeForce 980 I could conquer Japan.

10/10 wouldn't convert again to Christ, will enjoy Buddamonks

EDIT: a friend of mine found me, I own a GeForce 970, not a 980. Was trying to cheat the enemy into thinking my forces on field were greater. Sun Tzu docet.

reviewText: I have this game on disk and it's always been one of my favorites.  I was very unhappy when it would no longer run on my newer computers.  When I discovered it by accident on Steam (through a Humble Bundle), I did a happy-dance.  It plays fine although I did experience one non-crucial bug when I couldn't manually save.  That resolved upon restart of the game with the Autosave file.\n\nNow, if somebody would make the original Empire Earth playable on newer computers, I'd be even happier.

reviewText: Old school is sometimes the best fun! A great blast from the past and a whole lot simpler than some of the newer TW incarnations - if you're more into the Risk version than moving from town to town in the newer TWs, consider picking this one up!

reviewText: Nostalgia!\n\nI played this game LIKE CRAZY in the early 2000's. There was nothing else quite like it in those days... being able to lead mass armies into field battles where tactical movement was actually a thing. The Risk" setup of the campaign map has its benefits too
date: giving the feel of this being a board game with the added benefit of being able to actually fight the battles that your pieces are involved in.\n\nAlthough by now Shogun 1 is horribly outdated and is incomparable to its sequel Shogun 2
recommended: I have to give this a "yes" for both nostalgia and for being a genuinely good and innovative game when it first arrived. The good old days. :3\n\nI never did finish all those historical battles though... :("

reviewText: The best title in the series. Low amount of different units, but extremely deep combat. You are able to win battles with just moving your army around into better positions and demoralizing the enemy. The only RTS where you are punished for micromanaging your units - it will just tire them and you will lose strength. Loving it :)\nTry to read Sun Tzu The Art of War"
date: it will really help you get better in this game.\n\nGraphical glitches seem to be solved (No menu flicker)."

reviewText:
Why should you get this if you have already Shogun 2? I would say for me it's the risk style campaign map that gives you far more decisive battles. The multiple start dates are a bonus as is the Mogolian Invasion expansion.

Nostalgia not required to play this very good game which started the Total War series.

Playing this at 1024x768 for the campaign map and battles without any crashes in Win 8.1

The only bug there is that the audio cuts out the last few sentances of the advisor and diplomats speech in the throne room. You can always turn the throne room off in options. Nothing game breaking.

If you enjoy this I recomend getting Medieval 1 which is the second game in the Total War series which is also on Steam

reviewText: Nothing like getting to the root of the Total War series. This game obviously is not as good as Shogun 2. But the nostalgia is just too much. The game was actually very well optimized and runs very smooth. Graphics aren't great, but for a game made in 2000, it's just amazing. The game's soundtrack has a lot of the music featured in Shogun 2, along with a few other tracks that didn't make it to the sequel. If you've played games like Shogun 2 or Rome, you might be thrown off by these very different controls and battle commands.  This game is a must buy for any total war fan in the mood for something classic.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Really like this game, have it on disk too. But this steam version has a wierd sound bug where speech in the throne room will suddenly cut off about half way. I've had it happen on 2 different computers. Although it is a small thing though. It works otherwise and this version is more friendly to new computers.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Oh, how I am pleased to see the, arguably, best in the Total War series on Steam (Medieval Total War may be more loved by others). It is the original and retains all the best a strategy game can offer along with an AI that is intelligent and fun to play against. The late 90s and early 2000s were the best time for strategy games and this is one that proves the point.

If you have never played this and like strategy games, then you must give it a try. This and Medieval Total War are, by far, better than any of the successors. Rome Total War was the start of the decline in the Total War series.

Now that the game has been updated to work on modern systems, there is no reason not to buy this gem!

reviewText: One of the all time great rts games. reviewText:
*Sunglasses*

YEAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHH

The only TW game I've ever had a consistently easy time finishing campaigns on (Rome 1 being second) makes it stand out among the titles on one of their biggest pitfalls as a game. I'd also rank it as more polished in many ways than any title but Shogun 2. For those new to the games I'd put it over Rome 1 and Med 2 for accessibility - really worth getting for new players or veterans. Audio clips are cutting out on me and the screen flickers between screens but other than that it's playing well for me. Turn on the throne room in the settings and wonder why Rome 2 diplomacy isn't as cool!

reviewText: I've only played it briefly so far, but despite its age, it's a solid title. votesFunny: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
First of all, this game is ancient. There is nothing one can say about Total War Shogun which can dissprove that it is old. However, being the person I am, I decided to play all of the Total War series  and played Total War Shogun. The game in itself is pretty clunky (perks of being old) and lacks the depth of other Total War games. The real time battle squences are probably the clunkiest part of the game as they are slow and pixelated. Sometimes I couldn't even see what was going on. The game IMO is a bit easier and more straightforth compared to other Total War games (which is probably because of the lack of depth being the very first one in the series).

In my playthrough, I conquered all of Japan and became the Shogun :) For those who played this when it came out, Total War Shogun was extremely fun and groundbreaking. However, because I am playing this game in 2016 (16 years later I believe), I cannot recommend this game based on todays standards. But if you are playing the game for some early Total War fun and can bear through the graphics, then go ahead an play this. Otherwise go play Shogun II.

Rating: 6.2/10

reviewText:
This game...
He's very bad. Graphic are ugly, it's a shock when you know that Age of Empire II has better graphic.
The gameplay is the worst thing ever, especially if you starts with Rome Total War or a game after that.  Left click instead of left click (still better than Imperial Glory's gameplay).
The campaigns are good, seriously, this is the best point in this game, I wish we could have a mod or something to play the Mongol Invasion. Management is so bad,  you know what you build at the end of the turn, when you couldn't  do anything.
The  AI is stupid also, there is no challenge.  It's a torture to move your armies over the map because you HAVE NO IDEA how long they can walk. You could go from one province's point to one extr√™me point in the same province but you can't do more.
The battlefield also make you sick. Your units run and can't stop running which make them tired at the end. And a tired unit is so weak...OMG. You can't see the ennemy. Actually, this is a good point. But when you played, it's impossible.

If you want this game, wait until it costs 1$/‚Ç¨

reviewText:
This Game isn't Pretty and It's Old, but if you're willing to play this like the Boardgame Risk It can be quite nice, But you Really need to like this kind of play,

Auto Resolve, resolves a lot of the pain of the game, though You'll be working the dice, you can drag the unit cards on the campaign map unto another of the Same to combine the two which really would be your only way of really maintaining the offensive atleast So i Found,
I play the game like a Strategic Warfare Management Game,

It's important to note the Two Islands have a lot of Chokepoint opportunity where if you start from them you can really easily fortify and Hold your positions making the clans starting at that end very Easy, also If you play it smart you probably can move accross the map in a Sweeping motion in which you can just keep 1 front if you play your cards right,

Most of all, the sentiment was the trigger which inclined me to buy Shogun: Total War. It took me 3 hours to complete the game. I'm not a fan of battles so I decided to settle them with the help of AI. I really enyojed the medieval climate of Japan and the possibility to change the course of history in this part of the world.

This interesting title with low requirements will satisfy every gamer, who likes strategies and doesn't possess a mighty PC.
